content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE metadata SYSTEM "http://thor-f5.er.usgs.gov/ngtoc/metadata/fgdc-std-001-1998.dtd"> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>         <pubdate>201308</pubdate>         <title>USGS Small-scale Dataset - 100-Meter Resolution Natural Earth of the Conterminous United States 201308 TIFF</title>         <geoform>Raster digital data</geoform>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Rolla, MO</pubplace>           <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink>http://dds.cr.usgs.gov/pub/data/nationalatlas/nate48i0100a.tif_nt00867.tar.gz</onlink>         <lworkcit>           <citeinfo>             <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>             <pubdate>2013</pubdate>             <title>Small-scale Datasets</title>             <onlink>https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/532c5b23e4b0cd7393d07783</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </lworkcit>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract> This map layer contains a natural-earth image of the conterminous United States.  The image is land  cover in natural colors combined with shaded relief, which produces a naturalistic rendition of the  Earth's surface.  The data set is in an Albers Equal-Area Conic projection.  The Natural Earth data  were produced from existing National Atlas land cover, tree canopy, elevation, and satellite view  data.  </abstract>       <purpose> The 100-meter resolution Natural Earth data were developed to portray the terrain and land cover of  the United States at 1:1,000,000 scale.  They are intended primarily for visual purposes.  The  original NLCD data or Landsat Thematic Mapper imagery data should be used for conducting scientific  analysis, and the original NED data should be used for determining the most accurate elevation  values.  No responsibility is assumed by the National Atlas of the United States in the use of  these data.  </purpose>       <supplinf> Most National Atlas TIFF files can be loaded into Photoshop, however, this data set exceeds the  regular Photoshop size limits.  The National Atlas offers a Photoshop Large Document (.psb) version  of the data at http://nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp-1m.html; see the Distribution Information,  below, for more information.    Included with the GeoTIFF are an information file (.xml), an auxiliary information file (.aux.xml),  an image overview file (.ovr), a .tfw file (more information included below), and a .prj file (more  information included below.)    The contents of the associated world file (.tfw) are:  >100.0  >0.0  >0.0  >-100.0  >-2539950.0  >3257950.0    The projection (.prj) file contains the following information:  >PROJCS["Albers_NAD83_L48",  >GEOGCS["GCS_North_American_1983",  >DATUM["D_North_American_1983",  >SPHEROID["GRS_1980",6378137.0,298.257222101]],  >PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0],  >UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]],  >PROJECTION["Albers"],  >PARAMETER["False_Easting",0.0],  >PARAMETER["False_Northing",0.0],  >PARAMETER["Central_Meridian",-96.0],  >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_1",29.5],  >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_2",45.5],  >PARAMETER["Latitude_Of_Origin",23.0],  >UNIT["Meter",1.0]]    Data set extent in meters (Albers Equal-Area Conic projection)  >North 3258000  >West -2540000  >East 2441000  >South 119000    There are no NULL or NODATA values in the GeoTIFF.  Instead, all oceans are assigned a RGB color of  (193, 224, 250) (blue) and all non-U.S. land is assigned a RGB color of (240, 235, 211) (tan).    Information about National Atlas Web services can be found on the Web Map and Web Feature Services  page; see http://nationalatlas.gov/infodocs/webservices.html.  ; {"gdaId" : 6065791}</supplinf> <geoform>Raster digital data</geoform>             <onlink>http://nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp-1m.html</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </srccite>         <srcscale>1000000</srcscale>         <typesrc>Online</typesrc>         <srctime>           <timeinfo>             <sngdate>               <caldate>201212</caldate>             </sngdate>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>Publication date</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>Elevation US 100M</srccitea>         <srccontr>Spatial and attribute information.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <procstep>         <procdesc> The Natural Earth image is a combination of land cover in natural colors and shaded relief.    The shaded relief part of the image was created from the National Atlas Elevation data.  Relief  was rendered with Natural Scene Designer Pro 6.0.  The original 100-meter data were down-sampled  to 200 meters and received one application of smoothing in NSD Pro 6 prior to relief rendering.  Light azimuth = 315 degrees, angle = 45 degrees.    Relief was rendered with 200 percent vertical exaggeration in the western US; 300 percent  exaggeration in the Appalachians, Adirondacks, Ouachitas, and Ozarks; and 400 percent  exaggeration in flat areas of the Midwest and east.    Shaded relief was composited in Adobe Photoshop CS6.  The Avenza Geographic Imager 4.1 plug-in  for Photoshop maintained georeferencing of the shaded relief image.  In Photoshop, the relief is  composed of four layers that print above land cover: global illumination, high mountain  illumination, global shadows, and high mountain shadows.  Illumination prints as transparent  white, global shadows as transparent black, and high mountain shadows as transparent gray blue.    The land cover part of the image was derived from the National Atlas Land Cover, Tree Canopy, and  Satellite View data sets.  These products were re-colorized and blended in Photoshop to create  land cover with natural colors.    The Landsat images (satellite view) are most evident in the arid western United States.  They  also appear as subtle textures in cropland, wetland, and tundra areas.    Using "dissolve" blending mode in Photoshop for layers containing NLCD forest data (Land Cover  and Tree Canopy) created a slightly pebbled surface to mimic a natural forest canopy.    To eliminate small urban areas from the image, urban areas were extracted from the Land Cover  data set, aggregated, placed on a layer mask in Photoshop, and a 1-pixel Median filter was  applied.    Lava received a slight "sandstone" texture created with Photoshop's texturizer filter.    Inland water bodies were removed from the land cover with Photoshop's "content aware" fill tool.  Manual touch-ups afterwards repaired discordant fill textures.    All land cover received 0.7 application of Gaussian blur prior to merging it with the shaded  relief.  </procdesc>         <srcused>Land Cover US 100M</srcused>         <srcused>Tree Canopy US 100M</srcused>         <srcused>Satellite View US 100M</srcused>         <srcused>Elevation US 100M</srcused>         <procdate>2013</procdate>       </procstep>       <procstep>         <procdesc> Ocean areas were assigned a RGB value of (193,224,250) (blue) and non-U.S. land was assigned a  value of (240,235,211) (tan).  </procdesc>         <procdate>2013</procdate>       </procstep>
